repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
# Problem

Language names are only registered for filetype<->language lookups when parsers are actually loaded; this means users cannot rely on `vim.treesitter.language.get_lang()` or `get_filetypes()` to return
the correct value when language and filetype coincide and always need to add explicit fallbacks.

# Solution

 Always return the language name as valid filetype in `get_filetypes()`, and default to the filetype in `get_lang()`. Document this behavior.

Supersedes #30353

---

# Problem

No clear way to check whether parsers are available for a given language.

# Solution

Make `language.add()` return `true` if a parser was successfully added and `nil` otherwise. Use explicit `assert` instead of relying on thrown errors.

Cf. #30382 

---

Do not squash.

---

Note to self: needs (trivial) adapting for in nvim-treesitter and telescope.

comment_data.body: @zeertzjq I can't find where the help files talk about this feature. Is there some standard terminology I can use instead?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -979,6 +982,11 @@ get_filetypes({lang})                *vim.treesitter.language.get_filetypes()*
         (`string[]`) filetypes
 
 get_lang({filetype})                      *vim.treesitter.language.get_lang()*
+    Returns the language name to be used when loading a parser for {filetype}.
+
+    If no language has been explicitly registered via
+    |vim.treesitter.language.register()|, default to {filetype}. For composite
+    filetypes like `html.glimmer`, only the main filetype is returned.

comment_data.body:
Future note: This appears to be the dual of `register()`. Can we name register() to `set_lang()` ? 

We do not use the name "register" anywhere else in stdlib AFAICT, and this thankfully looks like the last such usage.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -979,6 +982,11 @@ get_filetypes({lang})                *vim.treesitter.language.get_filetypes()*
         (`string[]`) filetypes
 
 get_lang({filetype})                      *vim.treesitter.language.get_lang()*
+    Returns the language name to be used when loading a parser for {filetype}.

comment_data.body: No, `set_lang` implies you set _the_ language; this adds it to a "register". I don't think there's a precedent in the API for this. (`add` would work, but that's already taken.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -979,6 +982,11 @@ get_filetypes({lang})                *vim.treesitter.language.get_filetypes()*
         (`string[]`) filetypes
 
 get_lang({filetype})                      *vim.treesitter.language.get_lang()*
+    Returns the language name to be used when loading a parser for {filetype}.

@@ -979,6 +982,11 @@ get_filetypes({lang})                *vim.treesitter.language.get_filetypes()*
         (`string[]`) filetypes
 
 get_lang({filetype})                      *vim.treesitter.language.get_lang()*
+    Returns the language name to be used when loading a parser for {filetype}.

comment_data.body:
True, and that could work, but I feel that that would be confusing with `vim.treesitter.language.add` (which is... not a great name).

To be blunt: without a complete rethink of the API, this sort of thing is putting lipstick on a pig...
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+    Returns the language name to be used when loading a parser for {filetype}.

+    Returns the language name to be used when loading a parser for {filetype}.
+
+    If no language has been explicitly registered via
+    |vim.treesitter.language.register()|, default to {filetype}. For composite
+    filetypes like `html.glimmer`, only the main filetype is returned.

comment_data.body: Worst documented feature ever ;) I think that should be somewhere in `:h filetype` -- I've seen repeated misunderstandings of how this works...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -979,6 +982,11 @@ get_filetypes({lang})                *vim.treesitter.language.get_filetypes()*
         (`string[]`) filetypes
 
 get_lang({filetype})                      *vim.treesitter.language.get_lang()*
+    Returns the language name to be used when loading a parser for {filetype}.
+
+    If no language has been explicitly registered via
+    |vim.treesitter.language.register()|, default to {filetype}. For composite
+    filetypes like `html.glimmer`, only the main filetype is returned.

comment_data.body: Nit: it looks like the other bulleted lists in these sections do not have empty lines in-between list items
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -88,6 +88,16 @@ TREESITTER
   backwards compatibility, an option `all=false` (only return the last
   matching node) is provided that will be removed in a future release.
 
+• |vim.treesitter.language.get_filetypes()| always includes the {language}
+  argument in addition to explicitly registered filetypes.
+
+• |vim.treesitter.language.get_lang()| falls back to the {filetype} argument
+  if no languages are explicitly registered.
+

@@ -71,53 +76,54 @@ end
 
 --- Load parser with name {lang}
 ---
---- Parsers are searched in the `parser` runtime directory, or the provided {path}
+--- Parsers are searched in the `parser` runtime directory, or the provided {path}.
+--- Can be used to check for available parsers before enabling treesitter features, e.g.,
+--- ```lua
+---   if vim.treesitter.language.add('markdown') then
+---     vim.treesitter.start(bufnr, 'markdown')
+---   end
+--- ```
 ---
 ---@param lang string Name of the parser (alphanumerical and `_` only)
 ---@param opts? vim.treesitter.language.add.Opts Options:
+---@return boolean? True if parser is loaded
 function M.add(lang, opts)
   opts = opts or {}
   local path = opts.path
-  local filetype = opts.filetype or lang
   local symbol_name = opts.symbol_name
 
   vim.validate({
     lang = { lang, 'string' },
     path = { path, 'string', true },
     symbol_name = { symbol_name, 'string', true },
-    filetype = { filetype, { 'string', 'table' }, true },
   })
 
   -- parser names are assumed to be lowercase (consistent behavior on case-insensitive file systems)
   lang = lang:lower()
 
   if vim._ts_has_language(lang) then
-    M.register(lang, filetype)
-    return
+    return true
   end
 
   if path == nil then
+    -- allow only safe language names when looking for libraries to load
     if not (lang and lang:match('[%w_]+') == lang) then
-      error("'" .. lang .. "' is not a valid language name")
+      return
     end
 
     local fname = 'parser/' .. lang .. '.*'
     local paths = api.nvim_get_runtime_file(fname, false)
     if #paths == 0 then
-      error("no parser for '" .. lang .. "' language, see :help treesitter-parsers")
+      return
     end
     path = paths[1]
   end
 
   if vim.endswith(path, '.wasm') then
-    if not vim._ts_add_language_from_wasm then
-      error(string.format("Unable to load wasm parser '%s': not built with ENABLE_WASMTIME ", path))
-    end
-    vim._ts_add_language_from_wasm(path, lang)
+    return vim._ts_add_language_from_wasm and vim._ts_add_language_from_wasm(path, lang)
   else
-    vim._ts_add_language_from_object(path, lang, symbol_name)
+    return vim._ts_add_language_from_object(path, lang, symbol_name)

comment_data.body: returning extra data is not usually considered breaking.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -87,6 +87,13 @@ TREESITTER
   capture IDs to a list of nodes that need to be iterated over. For
   backwards compatibility, an option `all=false` (only return the last
   matching node) is provided that will be removed in a future release.
+• |vim.treesitter.language.get_filetypes()| always includes the {language}
+  argument in addition to explicitly registered filetypes.

comment_data.body: It's not extra, it's returning where it used to not return -- and it's reasonable to assume that some people relied on the `nil` to be able to, e.g., do something else instead of starting treesitter. We could claim this falls under "treesitter is experimental", but I thought it better to err on the side of caution and give a shoutout here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -87,6 +87,13 @@ TREESITTER
   capture IDs to a list of nodes that need to be iterated over. For
   backwards compatibility, an option `all=false` (only return the last
   matching node) is provided that will be removed in a future release.
+• |vim.treesitter.language.get_filetypes()| always includes the {language}
+  argument in addition to explicitly registered filetypes.

comment_data.body:
@lewis6991 This may prioritize a wasm parser over a native one even though we may not build with WASM and then fail.

On the other hand, we would happily have tried to load a `python.borkbork` even before that... (And the issue will be irrelevant anyway once we enable wasmtime by default.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -96,29 +102,27 @@ function M.add(lang, opts)
   lang = lang:lower()
 
   if vim._ts_has_language(lang) then
-    return
+    return true
   end
 
   if path == nil then
+    -- allow only safe language names when looking for libraries to load
     if not (lang and lang:match('[%w_]+') == lang) then
-      error("'" .. lang .. "' is not a valid language name")
+      return
     end
 
     local fname = 'parser/' .. lang .. '.*'
     local paths = api.nvim_get_runtime_file(fname, false)
     if #paths == 0 then
-      error("no parser for '" .. lang .. "' language, see :help treesitter-parsers")
+      return
     end
     path = paths[1]
   end
 
   if vim.endswith(path, '.wasm') then
-    if not vim._ts_add_language_from_wasm then
-      error(string.format("Unable to load wasm parser '%s': not built with ENABLE_WASMTIME ", path))
-    end
-    vim._ts_add_language_from_wasm(path, lang)
+    return vim._ts_add_language_from_wasm and vim._ts_add_language_from_wasm(path, lang)

comment_regular_data.body: @echasnovski could you please check whether this still works for built-in comments? (Seems to be in my brief test, but I may have missed some edge cases.)

Note that this is in effect a change in meaning: Before, the functions returned _actual_ associations (reliable because they were added manually or only on successful loading); now they return _potential_ associations.

But that validation was never really fully usable since nvim-treesitter registered all languages upfront, even if a user did not install them. So I think this is the better meaning, and how it is actually used.

> @echasnovski could you please check whether this still works for built-in comments? (Seems to be in my brief test, but I may have missed some edge cases.)

I also don't notice issues after some testing. It also seems to be more or less fine after looking at code, because the worst that can happen is [this `vim.filetype.get_option()`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/3b54adc6c6d25dd146fa1eac21321f6bd612f50a/runtime/lua/vim/_comment.lua#L38) returning default global 'commentstring', which arguably should be `''` and later ignored. So should be fine.

------

That said, I'd personally find it somewhat confusing mixing filetype and language abstractions. Especially after the period of their careful separation.

Is it certain that there will never be a language name that is spelled like some used filetype *but* has differently named "primary" filetype? Because if not, then this change will bring trouble.

Also (at least current implementation) may result into duplicating entries (like `vim.treesitter.language.get_filetypes('lua')`), which is somewhat confusing.

Thanks for checking!

> That said, I'd personally find it somewhat confusing mixing filetype and language abstraction.

It's not, though; this is just explicitly handling _in these functions_ the default link that is already made elsewhere (e.g., `vim.treesitter.start()`).

> Is it certain that there will never be a language name that is spelled like some used filetype but has differently named "primary" filetype? Because if not, then this change will bring trouble.

Then you simply register it, which overrides the fallback. Otherwise I'd propose to wait for this to actually happen so we can deal with the concrete issues that arise.

> Also (at least current implementation) may result into duplicating entries (like vim.treesitter.language.get_filetypes('lua')), which is somewhat confusing.

How? Because you explicitly did `vim.treesitter.language.register('lua', 'lua')`? (You shouldn't do this anymore; that's why the commit is marked as "breaking".)

> How? Because you explicitly did `vim.treesitter.language.register('lua', 'lua')`? (You shouldn't do this anymore; that's why the commit is marked as "breaking".)

I do not have this explicitly in the config. The culprit seems to be `master` branch of 'nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter'. Having done `:packadd nvim-treesitter` makes this duplication appear.
As I said, it's a breaking change, and plugins need to adapt. I'll handle this in nvim-treesitter. But is this really breaking anything?

> But is this really breaking anything?

Not that I can think of right now. Just "... is somewhat confusing.".

> `vim.treesitter.language.register('lua', 'lua')`? (You shouldn't do this anymore; that's why the commit is marked as "breaking".)

That practical example may be worth mentioning in the news item.

> That practical example may be worth mentioning in the news item.

Nah, the only one who'd be doing that is me, and I'll just stop.
Todo: figure out how this factors into https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/3b54adc6c6d25dd146fa1eac21321f6bd612f50a/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/languagetree.lua#L737
Changed the return values of `language.add()` to `true` or `nil,errmsg` as discussed.

title: feat(treesitter)!: remove unnecessary side effects from  `language.add` and add return value
